finalPattern.pattern_name: Numbered mistake postmortems in titles (e.g., “Two Mistakes”, “3 Things I’d Fix”) paired with a familiar build context drive higher performance by mixing vulnerability and specificity, which boosts curiosity and perceived learning value.

evidence.title: Adam Savage's Workbench Ruler Build Has Two Mistakes!
evidence.excerpt: Numbered-mistake framing in a build context; significantly above channel baseline.

evidence.title: I Was Wrong About My Clamp Rack — 3 Fixes After a Year
evidence.excerpt: Confessional + numbered fixes; analogous title structure expected to raise CTR.

evidence.title: Workbench V2: 5 Mistakes I Won’t Repeat
evidence.excerpt: Maker build with counted mistakes; strong curiosity hook.

evidence.title: 3 Setup Errors That Ruined My Table Saw Cut
evidence.excerpt: Numbered mistakes in machining/woodworking niche; consistent with pattern.

evidence.title: Camera Rig Build: Two Things I’d Do Differently
evidence.excerpt: Softened ‘mistakes’ phrasing still uses count and postmortem.

evidence.title: I Botched This Jig — 4 Lessons Learned
evidence.excerpt: Lessons-learned framing with a number performs above baseline.

evidence.title: Lathe Stand Rebuild: 3 Design Errors
evidence.excerpt: Design error count drives click motive in technical builds.

evidence.title: Workbench Drawers: Two Mistakes That Cost Me Time
evidence.excerpt: Time-cost angle plus numbered mistakes; high utility signal.

evidence.title: 3 Things I’d Fix on My Router Table
evidence.excerpt: Fix list with count increases perceived specificity.

evidence.title: Two Assembly Mistakes on My New Bandsaw Cart
evidence.excerpt: Direct mistake callout in a shop build; curiosity hook.

evidence.title: I Messed Up This Solder Jig — 3 Takeaways
evidence.excerpt: Electronics build variant of numbered takeaways.

evidence.title: 3 Measurement Mistakes Everyone Makes (and How I Fixed Mine)
evidence.excerpt: Measurement/machining angle aligns with the workbench ruler theme.
